issues.title: Disallow Informational Protection Error Causes?
issues.author: gloinul
issues.body: If we allow protection engines that lack informational or temporary error exchange then there is some risk that the unknown SCTP error chunk will be propagated to the ULP rather than the protection enginge. In such cases there is a significant risk that the error chunk leads to SCTP association termination.

comments.author: gloinul
comments.body: Likely can be closed, but @gloinul will do a review of the whole document to verify that this is no longer relevant.

comments.author: gloinul

issues.title: Clarify how path selection is done for protection engine packets
issues.author: gloinul
issues.body: Michael Tüxen review noted that we does not discuss how path selection for the protection engine created packets work. This also comes with an additional issue that needs to be clarified. Namely how path failures are handled. So if no SCTP packets are sent but protection engine sends packet then the SCTP stack is not aware of these packets and do not notice that they are not acknowledged by the peer protection engine. Some mechanism will be needed here to handle this case.

comments.author: teiclap
comments.body:
Actually SCTP protocol helps here.
SCTP stack does continuously supervise the paths either with traffic or with path probing using HB/HB-ACK.
The selection of the current path is done at SCTP thus messages belonging to protection engine will exploit that path.
We are not including CRYPTO chunks in the account for SACK assuming that the encryption engine itself is able dealing with data loss and can wait until SCTP does probe the path.
A solution here may be simple, that is we do nothing so that we have a risk that the protection engine runs into timeout before SCTP switches to the alternative paths in case of multihoming. Such case would possibly happen when protection engine has internal data to be sent and the Upper Layer Application has no traffic for a long time.
Alternative is complex and requires a though interaction between protection engine and SCTP, it may be that in case of SCTP is idle then protection engine forces HB chunks to be sent. 
A simpler solution is to tune HB properly, for instance by sending an HB every 2 seconds or so. This we can provide as recommendation for the specific protection engine. In DTLS I'd see a good choice to have HB at 2 seconds rate.

comments.author: gloinul
comments.body: Thanks @teiclap there is clearly these trade-offs here. And I think we have to acknowledge what the impact would be if an SCTP stack runs either default timers or even known maximum on path keep-alive. As well as considering what impact of addressing this.

issues.title: SCTP Restart Handling
issues.author: teiclap
issues.body:
SCTP Restart allows an SCTP Endpoint that has experienced a restart to resume an Association towards a remote Endpoint.
In case of Crypto Chunk that would need sending unencrypted INIT chunk, but such traffic will be discarded at the remote Endpoint thus there's no way to handle SCTP Restart.
On the other hand once an SCTP Endpoint has a restart, all the resources are lost including the Protection Engine and its state.
Last but not the least, permitting SCTP Restart would in some way open up to association hijacking.
The proposal is to explicitly state that SCTP Restart case is not supported.

issues.title: ASCONF support
issues.author: teiclap
issues.body:
ASCONF chunk transports information that are used for the identification of the Association, this allows the SCTP Endpoint to recognize the SCTP packet even if it comes from an unknown IP address.
SCTP Crypto chunk doesn't allow reading the ASCONF chunk before being decrypted, thus SCTP Endpoint has no criteria for accepting the SCTP packet based on ASCONF information.
It's suggested to fix that problem by describing the procedure to be used when as SCTP Endpoint supports ASCONF.
In case ASCONF is supported, the SCTP Endpoint will use the VTAG for giving a first criteria of acceptability, if the VTAG is known the Crypto Chunk will be sent to the Protection Engine for processing.

issues.title: Support for Kernel implementation of SCTP
issues.author: teiclap
issues.body:
OpenSSL relies on a lot of things that exist only in userspace such as [use of PThreads library] and [custom memory allocation].
The implementation of Crypto Chunks in kernel space is challenging for kernel SCTP implementations as it can do encryption/decryption using kernel crypto API but it cannot handle the SSL protocols such as DTLS.
It should be possible to redesign Crypto Chunks in a way that allows kernel SCTP implementation exploiting SSL protocols running in user space and crypto libraries in kernel space.

issues.title: ASCONF requires SCTP-AUTH
issues.author: gloinul
issues.body:
RFC 5061 requires that the ASCONF chunk is protected by SCTP-AUTH. That is unnecessary strict as source-authenticity is what is required. Thus, we will need to discuss with the WG if we should let Crypto Chunk simply update RFC 5061 Section 4.1.1 text:

> This chunk MUST be sent in an authenticated way by using the mechanism defined in [RFC4895].

pulls.title: Addressed the problem with inband key management
pulls.author: teiclap

comments.body: I think the Data Management part should likely be called "Protection Opertions" or something similar. I am also uncertain about the box. I would think that having the protection engine on the top. And then have the box Protection operations that exchange protected data and clear text with the crypto block, and then have keys being pushed down from the upper layers. One realization the protection operations happens embedded in the crypto block.

So, that this is true as soon one has reached "Established" state is fine. But what about before that? Should it use just plain text DATA chunks, however only the key-management PPID is allowed to be sent by the upper layers? Or should we like SCTP-AUTH have a null key? I think just using DATA until Established for the key-managment messages is the better operations and avoids opening up for using non-encrypted when you have reached established state.
Just checking that it is fine to throw away all plain text CHUNKS. Including ASCONF?
SHALL
More changes are needed a couple of paragraphs below this figure as it describes the protection engine initilization as sending crypto frames, not DATA chunks with a special PPID.
Also section 2.1 mentions SHUTDOWN-COMPLETE chunk. Is that wrong or do that need to be mentioned here?
SCTP Crypto chunk

This section likely need to update RFC 5061 to allow Crypto chunks using a protection engine with a cryptographic authentication of the packet to be used in stead of SCTP-AUTH as the mechanism to ensure source authenticity of the ASCONF chunk. Section 4.1.1 of RFC 5061 states: 
"This
   chunk MUST be sent in an authenticated way by using the mechanism
   defined in [RFC4895]."

I think this sentence is incorrect. To my understanding if one supports ASCONF and CRYPTO what will happen is that the arriving packet with the ASCONF chunk will first be looked up based on VTAG, then have the protection operation being run on it. Then the SCTP stacks chunk processing will take care of this ASCONF chunk that arrived in a autheticated packet. Noted that meta data about the arriving packet's source IP address may be required when the Address field in the ASCONF is null. And the Address field can't be used to locate the association context. Thus SCTP stacks with CRYPTO chunk support will have to use the VTAG + arrival port as the method for finding the right association and can't rely on source IP, which anyway ASCONF in some usages can't do either.

Can really duplicate VTAG occur on a set of ports? The SCTP endpoint will indicate the VTAG to use to identify the created association. That should never have duplicates. Only in cases when packets from an old association show up could this happen, and they will have different security context, thus the old packet will be dropped.

I think this likely can be better formulated. The core of the issue is that a restarting SCTP endpoint that want to recover the association would need to have the protection engine security context preserved over that restart so that it can send Crypto chunks which will be determined authentic with by the peer and also be capable of receiving that peers protected SCTP crypto chunks.
